drupalNodeEvent.title: Celebrating the Death of a Daughter: The Glory and Agony of the Father of a Chastity Martyr in Early Qing China

field_speakers.processed: Martin W. Huang (Professor, Department of East Asian Studies, University of California Irvine)

field_organizers.processed: Department of History, Jao Tsung-I Academy of Sinology & Mr. Simon Suen and Mrs. Mary Suen Sino-Humanitas Institute, HKBU

drupalNodeEvent.field_event_venue: SWT701 & 702, Shaw Tower, Shaw Campus, Hong Kong Baptist University

field_description.processed: Professor Huang's on-going project is tentatively titled "Husbands in Mourning: Bereavement, Memory and Gender in Late Imperial China." It concentrates on different kinds of elegiac writings by male literati on their deceased spouses in Ming-Qing China (approximately 16th-19th centuries), examining the questions of how womanhood was constructed and defined by men in a polygamous society and how such male reflections on womanhood in turn helped define these grieving authors’ own manhood in relation to their spouses as well as their male peers.
